item.title: Indrawati Signals Alignment with Prabowo, Says Budget on Target
item.description: Indonesia’s finance minister presented a unified front with President Prabowo Subianto, stressing that the government is committed to fiscal discipline while rolling out the new leader’s priority programs.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing, Haslinda Amin

media:content.media:description: Sri Mulyani Indrawati Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg Economics

item.title: Trump Enters Fraught Two-Week Run as Tax, Trade Deadlines Loom
item.description: Donald Trump’s frenzied second term enters a crucial stretch in the coming weeks as the president juggles a fragile ceasefire between Israel and Iran, a discordant party that he needs to pass his top legislative priority and a global economy on tenterhooks awaiting his next move on tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Cook

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: China Vows ‘Forceful Measures’ After Taiwan’s Huawei Export Curb
item.description: Beijing vowed to respond to Taiwan’s “technological blockades” after the self-ruled island blacklisted Chinese companies including Huawei Technologies Co., limiting their ability to develop cutting-edge artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Jing Li

media:content.media:description: Photo by PATRICIA DE MELO MOREIRA/AFP /AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: PATRICIA DE MELO MOREIRA/AFP

item.title: China Is Building a ‘Mega-Sized’ Consumer Economy, Premier Says
item.description: Premier Li Qiang has projected confidence that China can turn consumption into a driver for the economy, while also casting his nation as a stabilizing force in a rapidly shifting global trade landscape.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu, Linda Lew

media:content.media:description: Chinese Premier Li Qiang

item.title: Cuomo Concedes to Mamdani in NYC Democratic Mayoral Primary
item.description: Former New York Governor Andrew Cuomo conceded to his upstart rival Zohran Mamdani in the Democratic primary in the race to become mayor of New York City after the 33-year-old Queens lawmaker racked up commanding leads across Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: Laura Nahmias, Nacha Cattan, Gregory Korte

item.title: China’s Lan Laments Decline of Aid in Speech to Development Bank
item.description: China’s Finance Minister Lan Fo’an warned emerging countries are running short of money to spend on cross-border infrastructure, in remarks at a meeting of a multilateral lender based in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Fran Wang

media:content.media:description: China’s Finance Minister Lan Fo’an.

item.title: HUD Plans to Move Operations From Washington to Virginia
item.description: The US Housing and Urban Development Department, whose headquarters in Washington is up for sale, plans to move at least some of its operations into another federal building just outside the city amid a broader Trump administration campaign to consolidate government costs.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: The US Department of Housing and Urban Development headquarters in Washington, DC. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Baffles With Sudden U-Turn on China Buying Iranian Oil
item.description: President Donald Trump on Tuesday appeared to undermine years of US sanctions on Iran, giving its biggest customer China the green light to carry on buying its oil as he seeks to bolster a ceasefire with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Grant Smith, Ben Bartenstein, Daniel Flatley, Mia Gindis

item.title: China Tells Brazil Xi Jinping Will Miss BRICS Summit in Rio
item.description: President Xi Jinping will miss a meeting of BRICS leaders in Rio de Janeiro, according to a Brazilian official familiar with the matter, marking the first time the Chinese leader has skipped the summit since taking power.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias

media:content.media:description: Chinese President Xi Jinping NHAC NGUYEN / POOL / AFP/Getty Images Photographer: NHAC NGUYEN/Getty Images

item.title: Japan Protests Fresh Chinese Activity in East China Sea
item.description: Japan filed a complaint with China after detecting new construction activities in the East China Sea, according to a statement released by Japan’s foreign ministry on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Photo by Jam Sta Rosa/AFP via Getty Images Photographer: JAM STA ROSA/AFP

item.title: Early Report Suggests US Strikes Only Set Back Iran Nuclear Program by Months
item.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — A U.S. intelligence report suggests that Iran’s nuclear program has been set back only a few months after U.S. strikes and was not “completely and fully obliterated” as President Donald Trump has said, according to two people familiar with the early assessment.

media:content.media:description: Building damage across the Isfahan nuclear technology center in Iran on June 22.

item.title: Indonesia Cuts Outlay on Giant Free Meals Program to $21 Billion
item.description: Indonesia has trimmed spending plans for what could still be the world’s second-most expensive free meals program, offering modest relief from fiscal pressures as President Prabowo Subianto advances a host of big-ticket projects.
item.dc:creator: Eko Listiyorini, Agnieszka de Sousa

media:content.media:description: A student has lunch during a trial of the free meals program in Jakarta in 2024.

item.title: US Sees Limited Damage to Iran Atomic Sites as UN Watchdog Urges Inspections
item.description: American airstrikes had only a limited impact on Iran’s nuclear program, according to early US intelligence findings, as the United Nations watchdog urged fresh inspection of the sites.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio, Alex Wickham, Natalia Drozdiak

media:content.media:description: Overview of Fordow underground complex on June 22 after US strikes. Source: Satellite image ©2025 Maxar Technologies

item.title: US, Mexico Eye Import Quota in Trade Talks on Steel Deal
item.description: Trade negotiations between the US and Mexico are homing in on a possible quota system to reduce tariffs on a certain volume of steel imports, a move seen as assuaging concerns of American manufacturers of the metal.
item.dc:creator: Joe Deaux, Jennifer A Dlouhy, Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: A worker grinds a stainless steel tube at a steel manufacturing facility in Mexico City, Mexico, on Thursday, Feb. 6, 2025.

item.title: AI Titans Struggle to Use Rising Clout to Block State Regulation
item.description: Staunch opposition from a handful of Republican lawmakers is endangering the tech industry’s drive to attach a ban on state regulation of artificial intelligence to Donald Trump’s tax bill.
item.dc:creator: Oma Seddiq, Emily Birnbaum

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, June 23, 2025. President Donald Trump’s tax-and-spending agenda is nearing a climactic vote in the Senate this week in the wake of air strikes on Iran, which risk embroiling the US in a prolonged Middle East conflict.

item.title: Erdogan Meets Trump at NATO Summit to Reset US-Turkey Ties
item.description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan met US President Donald Trump on the sidelines of the NATO summit in The Hague late Tuesday in a bid to turn the page on strained relations between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Selcan Hacaoglu

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Recep Tayyip Erdogan at the White House in Washington, DC, in 2019.

item.title: Trump Administration Ordered to Return Man Deported in Error
item.description: A federal appeals court ordered the Trump administration to return a Salvadoran man who was deported from the US in early May as a result of an “inadvertent” and “improper” government error.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Hurtado

media:content.media:description: US ICE agents and other federal law enforcement agencies attend a pre-enforcement meeting in Chicago.

item.title: Tight NYC Mayoral Race Drives Donations to Groups Backing Cuomo, Mamdani
item.description: New Yorkers are facing a barrage of last-minute advertisements across social media, television and pamphlets in the closely-watched Democratic primary for Mayor, fueled by donations from hedge fund managers, business titans and advocacy groups.
item.dc:creator: Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: Voters cast their ballots at a polling station during the New York City mayoral Democratic primary in the Queens borough of New York, on June 24.

item.title: States Step Up Fight With Trump Administration on Grant Cuts
item.description: Nearly two dozen US states sued the Trump administration to stop it from using what they say is a budget loophole to cut billions of dollars in federal grants that were already approved by Congress.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: Brownstone buildings are seen from a rooftop near Kenmore Square in Boston, Massachusetts, U.S., on Tuesday, Oct. 7, 2014. Boston ranked fifth among U.S. cities in the value of commercial real estate transactions, averaging $332 per square foot, according to according to a second-quarter 2014 report from Real Capital Analytics and Transwestern. Photographer: Scott Eisen

item.title: FBI Shifts Focus From Immigration to Terrorism Amid Israel-Iran Conflict
item.description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is moving resources off immigration cases and back to counterterrorism, citing potential threats after the US launched airstrikes on Iranian nuclear sites and helped broker a ceasefire between Iran and Israel following nearly two weeks of fighting.
item.dc:creator: Myles Miller

media:content.media:description: The Los Angeles Federal Building in Palm Springs, California.

item.title: UK Will Buy Nuclear-Capable F-35s in Next Bid to Woo Trump
item.description: The UK said it would buy at least 12 new US-made F-35A fighter jets capable of carrying nuclear weapons, the latest attempt by Prime Minister Keir Starmer to curry favor with President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham

media:content.media:description: A US Air Force Lockheed Martin F-35A Lightning II military jet air display at the Paris Air Show in Paris, France, on Monday, June 16, 2025. The 55th Paris Air Show runs 16-20 June at Le Bourget airport.

item.title: NATO Tries to Use Charm to Keep Trump On Its Side
item.description: Donald Trump ensured that NATO’s high-stakes summit would be a nervy affair to the end as he flew in to The Hague fueling doubts about whether the US remains fully committed to defending its allies.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano, Stephanie Lai, Ania Nussbaum

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump arrives for a dinner at Huis ten Bosch Palace during the 2025 NATO Summit in The Hague, Netherlands, on June 24, 2025.

item.title: Japan Policy Chief Hits Back at US Call for 5% Defense Spending
item.description: Japan should focus on enhancing its defense capabilities, not chasing spending goals, the ruling party’s policy chief said, following Trump administration calls for US allies to target higher military expenditure.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama, Akemi Terukina

media:content.media:description: Itsunori Onodera, newly-appointed defense minister of Japan, arrives at the Prime Minister's official residence in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Aug. 3, 2017. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is reshuffling his ministers and party officials after a slump in popularity and a humiliating local election defeat. Photographer: Tomohiro Ohsumi/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Truce Gains Ground as Nuclear Watchdog Seeks Iran Access
item.description: Israel and Iran appeared to be honoring a ceasefire brokered by Donald Trump after the president lashed out at both sides for early breaches, while the UN nuclear watchdog urged a rapid resumption of inspections at Iranian atomic sites amid reports that US bombing failed to completely destroy them.
item.dc:creator: Alisa Odenheimer, Hadriana Lowenkron, Golnar Motevalli

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump speaks to members of the media on the South Lawn of the White House before boarding Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, June 24, 2025. Trump called on Israel to stop dropping bombs on Iran, calling it a “major violation” of a fragile ceasefire between the two countries he announced just hours ago. Photographer: Francis Chung/Politico

item.title: Golden Gate Bridge Operator Weighs DEI Retreat on Federal Funding Worry
item.description: The head of the transit district that runs San Francisco’s iconic Golden Gate Bridge wants to scrap an anti-racism resolution and a policy promoting social equity in its contracting process, citing concerns that the measures could jeopardize $400 million in US funding under President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Eliyahu Kamisher

media:content.media:description: The Golden Gate Bridge.

item.title: Trump Emerges From Mideast Intervention With a Victory-For Now
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, senior editor Joe Sobczyk looks at a consequential few days in Trump’s presidency. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Joe Sobczyk

item.title: Bessent Predicts Republicans Reach SALT Truce in 48 Hours
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said House and Senate Republicans can cut a deal on the state and local tax deduction within the next two days, resolving one of the key issues that has stymied President Donald Trump’s economic legislation.
item.dc:creator: Cam Kettles, Nacha Cattan

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent

item.title: Solar Stocks Soar as GOP Mulls Changes to Tax Credits in Bill
item.description: Shares of solar companies surged after a Republican Senator said lawmakers are discussing changes to a provision in President Donald Trump’s broad spending bill that would abruptly end tax credits for rooftop panels.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter, Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: Workers install solar panels at a home in San Francisco.

item.title: Trump Administration Restaffs National Security Council After Cutting Its Size
item.description: The White House has begun hiring more staff at the National Security Council, people familiar with the matter said, reversing course weeks after President Donald Trump significantly cut the size of the council and as the US confronts a host of foreign-policy crises.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan, Stephanie Lai, Natalia Drozdiak

media:content.media:description: The West Wing of the White House stands in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Wednesday, March 11, 2020. President Donald Trump said he'd make a statement Wednesday night on how he'll deal with coronavirus, as he met with Wall Street executives at the White House on the day the Dow Jones Industrial Average plunged into bear market territory.

item.title: Carney Says Canada’s Mines to Help Pay $110 Billion NATO Bill
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said Canada can meet a steep expected increase in its North Atlantic Treaty Organization obligations spending partly by leaning on the country’s bounty of critical minerals.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Seal

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada’s prime minister
